text.content: MY FAVORITE TOY
Juanito's robot is his most prized possession. It has glowing buttons and stands proudly on his bed by the sunny window.
Every day after school, he races to the living_room to play with it while his mom sips coffee at the scratched wooden table.
His little sister Luisa whines, "Let me try!" but Juanito shouts, "It's mine!"
On rainy days, they watch cartoons on the flickering TV, and he makes the robot march to the music.
Last week, the battery died during a big "battle" with Luisa's doll. Juanito sobbed until his dad fixed it in their tiny workshop.
Now the robot jumps, spins, and even "talks" with funny beeps. Juanito hugs it every night, whispering secrets.
His bicycle is rusty, but his robot? Perfect.
LOSING A TOOTH
Camila's wobbly tooth has driven her crazy for days. She fiddles with it using her tongue on the bumpy bus ride to school.
Her abuela promised a shiny coin from the "Ratón Pérez" if she tucks it under her pillow tonight.
At lunch, her brother Mateo teases, "Eat this banana—it'll yank it out!" Camila glares and checks the gap in her cracked mirror.
Tomorrow's the big soccer match, and she needs_to be tough.
That evening, the tooth plops into her soup mid-bite. Abuela cackles, handing her a peso. "Make a wish!"
Camila whispers, "I hope I score a goal." As she sleeps, she dreams of a tiny rat in a backpack, zooming through the sky on a bicycle, tossing teeth like confetti.
SHARING WITH CLASSMATES
Valentina's brand-new sneakers are ruined when Diego trips, splashing juice across the white fabric. "Oops!" he says, scrubbing them with his hoodie.
She fumes but later hands him her eraser during a quiz.
At lunch, they swap chips for cookies, and Diego shows her a viral dance from his favorite reggaeton star.
Their teacher catches them practicing in the hall and laughs. "Teamwork!" she says.
During the math test, Valentina slides Diego a pencil after his snaps. "Thanks," he murmurs.
After school, they kick a crumpled soda_can down the street, laughing.
Valentina realizes Diego isn't just clumsy—he's funny, and he shares his last candy bar. Maybe friendship is worth a few stains.
SHOULD I JOIN THE CLUB?
Sofía hesitates outside the art club room, staring at the colorful poster. Her jeans are hand-me-downs, and her sneakers are caked in mud, but her sketches fill three notebooks.
Carlos adjusts his glasses and nudges her. "Just go in! It's cheaper than the robotics club."
She grips her frayed backpack, imagining the other kids' designer clothes.
That night, she draws a comic about a girl joining a club—bold lines, bright colors.
The next morning, she takes a shaky breath and signs up. The teacher gasps at her portrait. "This is incredible!"
Now Sofía carries her sketchbook everywhere, even to the park. Carlos snaps photos of her work. "See? You belong here."
For the first time, Sofía imagines a future where her art matters more than her old shoes.
OVERCOMING FEAR
David's hands tremble as the packed metro lurches forward. Today's his first internship interview, but crowds make his chest tight.
A man jostles his shoulder, and his phone clatters to the floor. "Easy," says a woman in a suit, offering gum.
David counts stops, gripping the handrail.
At the office, his boss reviews the schedule warmly. "Nervous?" she asks. David nods.
At lunch, he hides in the break room until María from accounting shares her arepa. "I cried on my first day too," she admits.
Later, David decides to ride the metro home. This time, he notices a girl reading his favorite comic.
They chat about superheroes, and his fear melts. The city's noise feels quieter now, its streets less overwhelming.
That night, he texts María: "Thanks for the food." She replies, "Welcome to the team." David smiles. Maybe his future isn't so scary after all.
THE VALUE OF COMMITMENT
Javier's alarm_clock blares at 4:30 AM. He ties his steel-toed boots for another shift at the warehouse, where his manager barks orders.
Between stacking boxes, he reviews anatomy diagrams on his cracked phone—medical school is his dream, but his resume lacks fancy internships.
At night school, Professor Rojas circles the "skills section" in red. "Rewrite this," she says.
The bus home reeks of chemicals, but Javier focuses on his notebook, copying a professional format.
His mom leaves soup warming on the stove, though she worked double shifts at the clinic.
At 1 AM, he sets three alarms, icing his swollen knees.
The next morning, he spots a poster for a free pre-med workshop. His hands shake as he texts the number.
"One step at a time," he whispers, lacing his boots. The warehouse can't crush his future—not while he's still breathing.
